ygData.msgSnippet: Doesn t DecidingScope have by default TransclusionDecideRule with value 3? If you have this rule it might retrieve *some* inline images and pdf even if they

Doesn't DecidingScope have by default TransclusionDecideRule with
value 3? =
If you have this rule it might retrieve *some* inline images
and pdf even i=
f they are otherwise out of scope, depending on the rule
chain order?

I'm =
not an expert on these.

--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "sajid kha=
n" <assamhelp@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi,
> First I want to thank Mr.Gordon Mohr fo=
r the instant reply.
> I tried DecideRuleScope with following filters:
>   =
      1) Accept all urls
>         2) URIRegExpFilter - if urls match the f=
ilter, eliminate them.
> This is the regular expression:
>    .*(?i)(\\.(jp=
g|jpeg|gif|tiff|svg|pdf))$
> 
> 
> It still picks files ending in gif, jpeg=
...etc.
> 
> 
> I also tried domainScope with an exclude filter. It contain=
ed only a
> URIRegExpFilter which returns true if the regular expression is=
 matched.
> But still it is not working.
> 
> 
>         The urls of the gi=
f/pdf files, which get picked, match the
regular
> expression (tested using=
 a simple java program).
> That means the regular expression is fine.
> 
> =
I'm not sure where I'm going wrong here.
> 
> Regards,
> Sajid
> 
> 
> 
> O=
n 1/20/07, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...> wrote:
> >
> >   sajid khan wrote:
> > =
> Hi,
> > > I dont want to save images and pdf files while crawling under t=
he
> > > domainScope.
> > > So, I enabled the additionalScopeFocus filter a=
nd set it to
return false
> > > when the below reg exp is satisfied:
> > > =
.*(?i)(*\\.(jpg|jpeg|gif|tiff|svg|pdf))$*<
> > file://%5C%5C.%28jpg%7Cjpeg%=
7Cgif%7Ctiff%7Csvg%7Cpdf%29%29$/>
> > >
> > >
> > > In spite of this, gif a=
nd jpegs get picked up. I can see that
they're
> > > consuming a couple of =
MBs when I look at the crawl report.
> > > Can anybody please give pointers=
 on how to fix it or where I may be
> > going
> > > wrong?
> >
> > In the c=
lassic scopes, the additionalScopeFocus filter can rule things
> > in with =
a 'true' response, but not rule things out. A 'false' just
means
> > 'this =
isn't something to be extra-added' -- if the URL still is
accepted
> > by t=
he general scope, it's still in.
> >
> > That's why in the newer, recommend=
ed, and usually more efficient
> > DecideRule approach, every rule has both=
 a test *and* a decision to
> > apply. A proper sequence of rules can accom=
plish almost every effect
> > imaginable.
> >
> > In the classic scopes, to=
 rule things out, set up excludeFilters.
> >
> > If translating the classic=
 approach to the chain-of-decide-rules
> > approach, the rules would roughl=
y be...
> >
> > (1) Set initial decision to reject
> > (2) If seed, set dec=
ision to accept.
> > (3) If in 'focus' (domains in the case of DomainScope)=
, set
decision to
> > accept.
> > (4) If 'additional focus' filter applies,=
 set decision to accept.
> > (5) If transitively included by referring hops=
, set decision to
accept.
> > (6) If 'excluded' filter applies, set decisio=
n to reject.
> >
> > ...with the last decision applied winning.
> >
> > - G=
ordon @ IA
> >  
> >
>
